intro: [WRONG START] Rosa arvensis var. sepentina, commonly known as the field rose or creeping rose, is a perennial shrub native to Europe and parts of Asia. It is characterized by its sprawling growth habit, with arching stems that often root at the nodes. The plant produces small, fragrant pink or white flowers in late spring to early summer. Its leaves are compound, consisting of five to seven oval leaflets, and are covered in fine, silvery hairs. Rosa arvensis var. sepentina is adapted to thrive in disturbed soils and is often found in meadows, roadsides, and wastelands.
